data.title: The World Factbook
data.text:
August 29, 2024

Want to see where Africa's population lives? The World Factbook has population distribution maps for most African countries on the World and Regional Maps page -- just select the "population distribution" filter on the right-hand menu.

August 22, 2024

If you're looking for facts about the world's oceans, just scroll down a bit further on the home page -- you'll find links for all five ocean basins.

August 15, 2024

The US State Department's annual Trafficking in Persons Report has been released for 2024, and The World Factbook has just posted the new information and links to the report for the relevant countries.

August 8, 2024

As the Paris Olympics draw to a close, you can find details in The World Factbook about all those national anthems you heard during the medal ceremonies. And don't miss the anthem audio clips on each country's page, under the Government category!

August 1, 2024

The World Factbook has many more updates this week as economic data for 2023 continues to roll in, so check out the new info on topics like real GDP per capita, unemployment rate, imports, and exports.

July 25, 2024

Youâve got questions? Weâve got answers!Â The World Factbook has an FAQ page, with questions and answers organized by category. You can find out how often the Factbook is updated, the meaning of âdoubly landlocked,â how we round numbers, and much more.

July 18, 2024

Interested in cover artwork from World Factbooks past? Click on About in the upper-right corner of the home page, then scroll down to the Gallery of Covers for images going back to 1962.

July 11, 2024

This week, The World Factbook has updates for several data fields related to energy, including electricity access, electricity, electricity generation, nuclear energy, coal, petroleum, natural gas, carbon dioxide emissions, and energy consumption.

July 4, 2024

The United States celebrates Independence Day this week on July 4. If you'd like to see The World Factbook lists of the dates and names of independence days worldwide, just click on the Independence or National holiday headings in the Government category for any country.

June 27, 2024

Looking for a quick way to find World Factbook data from multiple countries for individual data fields? Click on Country Comparisons at the bottom of the home page for a handy compilation of over 50 of our data fields.

June 20, 2024

On today's date in 1782, the Second Continental Congress selected the bald eagle as the official symbol of the United States. If you'd like to find symbols for other countries, just go to The World Factbook's list of national symbols from around the world.

June 13, 2024

The United States celebrates Flag Day this week on June 14, and you can find every country's flag at the top of its World Factbook page. If you're looking for a complete list, scroll to the bottom of the home page and click on Flags of the World.

June 6, 2024

You may have noticed The World Factbook's population pyramid charts on individual country pages, but did you know that you can also find all those charts in one place? Under the References tab, click on Population Pyramids by Region for an easy way to scan through the charts for multiple countries.

May 30, 2024

Ever wonder what an acronym in one of our data fields stands for? No need to keep wondering -- The World Factbook has a comprehensive list of acronyms available under the References tab. Just click on Abbreviations, and then click on the first letter of the acronym in the box on the left-hand side of the page.

May 23, 2024

Our updates this week include new telephone data in the Communications category, for both fixed-line and mobile cellular subscriptions in most countries.

May 16, 2024

For this week's update, we're posting new data on average household expenditures per country, including food, alcohol, and tobacco.

May 9, 2024

We have another set of updates this week, this time focused on economics. The new data includes imported and exported commodities, top import and export partners, and agricultural products.

May 2, 2024

The World Factbook has updated several demographic fields -- including population, age structure, and birth rates -- for all countries with available data. Check out the new info under the "People and Society" category on each country's page, or you can find the list of country data for each field under the References tab -- just click on Explore under "Guide to Country Profiles."

April 25, 2024

The World Factbook has two useful updates that make its maps and data more accessible. First, the Maps page has been re-structured so now there are just two sections, World and Regional Maps and CIA Maps. Second, the individual pages for the UK's two Sovereign Base Areas on the island of Cyprus - Akrotiri and Dhekelia - have been combined into a single Akrotiri and Dhekelia page, where the data for each entity is listed together in each field.

April 18, 2024

Ever wonder what the Total fertility rate field represents or why it is useful? Not sure what is included and what is not included in the Total renewable water resources field? To answer questions like these and to better understand what The World Factbook's data represents, please visit the helpful Definitions and Notes section under the References tab.

April 11, 2024

The World FactbookÂ has recently updated its Geoparks field in the Environment category with UNESCO's 2024 additions to its list of designated Global Geoparks. The 18 new sites bring the total to 213 UNESCO Global Geoparks found in 48 countries. Shown are the Hopewell Rocks, eroded sandstone conglomerates, in Canada's Bay of Fundy. The bay is home to the Cliffs of Fundy, which have been a UNESCO Global Geopark since 2020.

April 4, 2024

In the Economy category, 19 fields have been updated, including data worldwide for Real GDP (purchasing power parity), Real GDP growth rate, Exports, Imports, and Exchange rates.

March 28, 2024

The Antarctica page and our five world oceans pages (Arctic Ocean, Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean, and Southern Ocean) have been carefully updated with information provided by the Department of Stateâs Bureau of Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs. Pictured is the blue ice covering Antarctica's Lake Fryxell, in the Transantarctic Mountains, which comes from glacial meltwater from the Canada Glacier and other smaller glaciers. Image courtesy of National Science Foundation.

March 21, 2024

Desert covers about 70% of this landlocked, sparsely populated African country.Â Its Okavango Delta is one of the few inland delta systems that does not flow into a sea or ocean.Â Instead, its waters drain into the sands of the Kalahari Basin.Â The delta is one of the most-biodiverse areas in Africa and sustains robust populations of some of the worldâs most endangered large mammals, including the cheetah, white and black rhinoceros, wild dog and lion.Â The Okavango Delta was designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2014. Can you name it? (hint: please refer to the Geography - note page and the National heritage page)

March 14, 2024

In the Government category, the "Diplomatic representation in the US" field has been updated. The most recent data includes foreign ambassadors to the US who presented their credentials to the president on February 27, 2024.

March 7, 2024

The UN has declared 2024 the International Year of Camelids to highlight how these animals are essential to the livelihoods and survival of millions of households (particularly indigenous families) in mountainous, arid, and semi-arid environments in more than 90 countries.Â The Camelidae family includes the vicuna, alpaca (domesticated form of vicuna), guanaco, and llama (domesticated form of guanaco) native to South America and the dromedary camel, Bactrian camel, and wild camel found in Asia, the Middle East, and North Africa.Â

Known for their cultural and social significance, the alpaca (pictured) and the llama have been used by native peoples in Peru and other parts of the Andes Mountains for thousands of years as work animals and sources of meat, fiber, milk, and fertilizer.Â Camelid wool is a mainstay of Peru's textile and clothing industries. To learn more about the industries of Peru and other countries, please visit The World Factbook's industries page.

February 29, 2024

This Caribbean Island nation and self-governing territory of the UK introduced its current flag on May 30, 1990. Â It features the British flag in the upper hoist-side quadrant, recognizing the countryâs relationship with the UK, and the national coat of arms in the center depicting three orange dolphins in an interlocking circular design jumping out of the sea, represented by a turquoise-blue field below them.Â The three dolphins, adopted from this island nationâs earlier Three Dolphin Flag, reflect the national motto:Â Unity, Strength, and Endurance.Â The dolphin is also a national symbol, and their circular arrangement on the flag represents continuity.Â Can you name this country?Â (hint: please refer to the Flags of the World page and the National Symbols page)

February 22, 2024

The World Factbook has recently updated its "Merchant marine" entry in the Transportation category with 2023 data. This entry provides the total and the number of each type of privately or publicly owned commercial ships for each country; military ships are not included. The five ship types are bulk carrier, container ship, general cargo, oil tanker, and other.

February 15, 2024

Would you like to see entries for a particular field for all countries and territories at the same time?Â You can! Just visit the Guide to Country Profiles page under the References tab. Listed are the Categories, Fields, and subfields of information generally available for every country and territory.Â Clicking on one of the field names will take you to a page with the fieldâs definition followed by an alphabetical listing of country and territory entries for that field. For example, this listing shows the total population data for all countries and territories.

February 8, 2024

In the Transnational Issues category, the Trafficking in persons entry has been updated with 2023 information from the State Departmentâs annual Trafficking in Persons Report.Â This year the State Department designated 26 countries as Tier 2 Watchlist (not meeting minimum standards to eliminate trafficking but making significant efforts to do so) and 24 as Tier 3 (not meeting minimum standards to eliminate trafficking and not making significant efforts to do so).

February 1, 2024

The World FactbookÂ is pleased to introduce a new entry in its Environment category - Geoparks! UNESCO Global Geoparks are single, unified geographical areas that use their geological significance, in connection with all other aspects of the areaâs natural and cultural heritage, to enhance awareness and understanding of key issues facing society, such as using our earthâs resources sustainably, mitigating the effects of climate change, and reducing natural hazard-related risks.Â Currently, 195 UNESCO Global Geoparks are found in 48 countries.

January 25, 2024

The World has more than 7,160 living languages.Â More languages are spoken in this country than in any other, with 839 indigenous languages.Â The country's official languages are Tok Pisin (an English-based creole) and English.Â Can you name it?Â (hint: see the languagesÂ page)

January 18, 2024

This British crown dependency's national flag is red with a three-legged emblem in the center, known as a triskelion.Â It consists of three curved or jointed segments spiraling from a common center, in this case depicting three armored legs with golden spurs joined at the thigh and bent at the knee with the toes pointing clockwise.Â Can you name this self-governing possession of the British crown?Â (hint: please search for British Crown dependencies on The World Factbook's dependency statusÂ page or visit the Flags of the World page)

January 11, 2024

These two countries have the highest and lowest life expectancy at birth. Life expectancy at birth compares the average number of years to be lived by a group of people born in the same year, if mortality at each age remains constant in the future. Can you name the respective countries? (hint: see the country comparison of life expectancy at birth).

January 4, 2024

This creole language is a mixture of Portuguese, Spanish, Dutch, English, and, to a lesser extent, French, as well as elements of African and Arawak languages. It is an official language in Aruba and Curacao and is spoken in other islands in the Dutch Caribbean. Can you name it? (hint: see the languages entry)

December 21, 2023

Three countries have a parrot as a national symbol, but only one also features the parrot on its national flag. Can you name it?

December 14, 2023

The World Factbook's 2023 cover, which features an artificial intelligence-assisted design, is now posted in the Gallery of Covers. The cover will serve as a link to the 2023 archive, when it is posted in January 2024.

December 7, 2023

Updates to several of the People and Society fields have been completed using the latest 2023 data from the US Census Bureau. Among the fields updated are: "Population," "Life expectancy at birth," and "Median age."

November 30, 2023

The World Factbook contains descriptions of the population distribution for the World, countries, and territories. Globally, six of the world's seven continents are widely and permanently inhabited. Asia is easily the most-populous continent with about 60% of the world's population (China and India together comprise over 35%), while Africa comes in second with over 15% of the earth's populace. Europe accounts for about 10%, North America 8%, South America almost 6%, and Oceania less than 1%. The harsh conditions on Antarctica prevent any permanent habitation.

November 23, 2023

This country's national flag is the only one in the world that is non-quadrilateral in shape. Instead, its flag is composed of two overlapping triangular pennants. Can you name this South Asian country? Check the flag images under References>Flags of the World.

November 16, 2023

Two of The World Factbook's World and Regional Maps have been updated in PDF and in JPG formats - the Political World and Physical World maps. Please check them out!

November 9, 2023

The World Factbook has updated its particulate matter emissions subfield with 2019 data. This information can be found in the Environment category under the "Air Pollutants" field.

November 2, 2023

The World Factbook has added a new appendix on language codes that includes two- and three-character codes. Language codes are critical in place names data where a single place may have multiple names or spellings from different languages. The new appendix designation is D-3: Language Data Codes and it joins two other data code entries, D-1: Country Data Codes (formerly Appendix D) and D-2: Hydrographic Data Codes (formerly Appendix E). The Factbook now includes 12 useful appendices.

October 26, 2023

Did you know that there are 21 World entities (20 countries and 1 dependency) with multiple time zones? They are Australia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ecuador, France, Greenland (part of the Danish Kingdom), Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Kiribati, Mexico, Micronesia, Mongolia, Netherlands, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Portugal, Russia, Spain, and the United States. In some instances, the time zones pertain to portions of a country that lie overseas. To see these multiple time zones represented on a map, see the Standard Time Zones of the World map included with the World and Regional Maps.

October 19, 2023

Travel Facts, one of The World Factbook's most-popular features, is now available in printable PDF format for over 200 countries and dependencies. The new design is easier to read and continues to be a handy reference for travelers.

October 12, 2023

Two new African organizations have been added to Appendix B: International Organizations and Groups; they are: the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR) and the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA).

October 5, 2023

On September 25, 2023, the United States recognized two Pacific Ocean self-governing entities in free association with New Zealand - the Cook Islands and Niue - as sovereign and independent states, bringing the total number of countries in The World Factbook to 197.

The free association status of the Cook Islands and Niue allows for a great deal of internal autonomy, but transfers responsibility for defense and foreign affairs to New Zealand. This status is similar to the free association relationship that the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and Palau (three other Pacific Island entities) enjoy with the United States and that are also recognized as independent countries.

September 28, 2023

The World Factbook is delighted to announce the addition of a new "Wonders of the World" field under World > Geography. This entry presents information on three groups of Wonders: The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, The New Seven Wonders of the World, and The World Factbook's Seven Natural Ultra-Wonders of the World.

The latter is the only entry in The World Factbook that has been independently compiled by the Factbook's staff and is not derived from some other source. The listing is one of 'Ultra-Wonders' because it consists of natural phenomena/spectacles that are the largest in their respective categories and thus cannot be exceeded. Check out the compilation, some of the Wonders may surprise you.

September 21, 2023

UNESCO recently inscribed 24 cultural sites and 3 natural sites representing 26 countries and entities to its World Heritage List. The 27 additions bring the total number of sites on the list to 1,184, consisting of 924 cultural, 221 natural, and 39 mixed sites. Updated entries for both the World and individual countries and entities can be found in the Government category under âNational heritage.â

September 14, 2023

In the People and Society category, the "Major infectious diseases" entry has been updated with the latest information from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and from the National Center for Medical Intelligence. The major changes for the CDC were dropping a number of countries from its global polio alert.

September 7, 2023

More than 25,000 islands are estimated to lie scattered across the vast Pacific Ocean; they are frequently divided into three large cultural regions: Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia. To find out what countries and territories make up each of these regions refer to Appendix F: Geographic Names.

August 31, 2023

The classic science fiction adventure novel, Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea, is one of Jules Verne's most famous and popular works. The title refers to the distance, not depth, traveled under various seas. A league is a unit of measure no longer used in today's World, but how far is 20,000 leagues converted to kilometers or nautical miles? Find the answer by consulting Appendix G: Weights and Measures. (Hint: the distance is more than twice the circumference of the Earth.)

August 24, 2023

The World Factbook is undertaking its own Space launch! In light of the growing interest in - and expanded use of - outer space, the Factbook has added a new Space category as well as a new Space Programs appendix! Â For countries with a national space program, information on the names of their "Space agency/agencies," "Space launch sites" (where applicable), and a general "Space program overview" have been included.

The new Appendix S: Space Programs expands on the country entries and provides a chronological overview of a countryâs key activities, programs, and milestones in the space sector and an estimate on government spending on space.Â There are currently space entries for more than 90 countries, but the list will grow as more countries develop national space programs.

August 17, 2023

What country has the largest proven crude oil reserves? Where are the wettest places on Earth? What percent of the World's population has never used the Internet? What is the most densely populated place on the Earth? The answers may surprise you. If you have not yet checked out The World Factbook's Special Products under the World entry, you are missing out. These unique compendia condense fascinating information about our World onto five special two-page summaries covering: The Human World, The Connected World, The Energy World, The Physical World, and The Economic World. Check them out, print them off, and impress your friends with this engrossing data drawn from the pages of the Factbook.

August 10, 2023

The World Factbook is delighted to recognize the ongoing Women's World Cup soccer tournament in Australia and New Zealand with eight special World Cup One-Page Country Summaries, one for each of the remaining quarterfinalists: Australia, Colombia, England (UK), France, Japan, Netherlands, Spain, and Sweden. The Summaries appear in the Factbook's World entry under the Introduction > âWomen's World Cup 2023â.

August 3, 2023

The World Factbook has added additional data to a number of non-EU countries that use the euro as their domestic currency â Andorra, the Holy See, Kosovo, Monaco, Montenegro, and San Marino. Some of these countries have formal agreements with the EU (e.g., Andorra), while others merely unilaterally use it as their currency (e.g., Kosovo).

July 27, 2023

In the Environment category, the "Food insecurity" field has been updated with the latest UN Food and Agriculture Organization information. For a number of countries, the disruption of grain exports from the Black Sea region has contributed to shortfalls in available food.

July 20, 2023

In the Energy category, the "Electricity access" field has been updated with the latest available (2021) data. Overall, 91.4% of the World's population has access to electricity. The World total without access is 757 million. Sub-Saharan Africa remains the region with the most people, 583 million, without access to electricity.

July 13, 2023

Did you know that there are 12 countries whose flags have no top or bottom? Those banners may be flown with either long edge on top without any notice being taken. To find out which countries have such flags - as well as a lot of other fascinating flag information - visit the World > "Flag description" entry.

July 6, 2023

According to the latest UN estimates, Indiaâs population recently (sometime this past spring) reached 1.425 billion people, equaling that of China. India will likely pull ahead of China by several million people by the end of the year. Chinaâs population could drop below 1 billion people by the end of the century.

June 29, 2023

âDemographic profilesâ for five European Nordic countries were recently added to the People and Society section in The World Factbook. The countries included are: Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden.

June 22, 2023

The World Factbook now includes a new field in the Energy category that describes âNuclear energyâ used for the production of electricity. The information covers all countries with operational nuclear reactors used to produce electricity; the information does not include research reactors. Subfields include the current number of operational nuclear reactors, theÂ number ofÂ nuclear reactors under construction, theÂ net capacity of operational nuclear reactorsÂ expressed in gigawatts (GW), theÂ percent of total electricity productionÂ from nuclear energy, theÂ percent of total energy producedÂ from nuclear energy, and theÂ number of nuclear reactors permanently shut down.

June 15, 2023

The World Factbook recently added a fourth set of larger and more detailed country maps. The new maps include: the Baltic countries of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania; the Central African Republic; the Democratic Republic of the Congo; France; Germany; Seychelles; and the Solomon Islands; as well as the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The total number of newly enhanced maps now stands at 60.

June 8, 2023

The Geospatial Information Authority of Japan recently announced that Japan included some 100,000 islands and islets, 14,125 of which had a circumference of at least 100 m (330 ft) and were officially counted. This number was more than twice the 6,852 that were announced by the Japan Coast Guard in 1987. Advances in surveying technology and the detailed representation of topographic features through digital mapping allowed for the greater accuracy. Only about 260 of the islands are actually inhabited.

June 1, 2023

The World Factbook has added a new âWorld biomesâ field to the Environment section of the World entry. A biome is a biogeographical designation describing a biological community of plants and animals that has formed in response to a physical environment and a shared regional climate. Biomes can extend over more than one continent. While different classification systems define different numbers of biomes, the Factbook recognizes the seven biomes used by NASA: Tundra, Coniferous Forest, Temperate Deciduous Forest, Rainforest, Grassland, Shrubland, and Desert.

The new entry includes a World Biomes map, as well as photos and detailed descriptions of each of biome.

May 25, 2023

In the Economy category, the âBudgetâ field â with its revenues and expenditures subfields â was recently updated with the latest available data.

May 18, 2023

In the Environment category, two water-availability fields â âTotal water withdrawalâ and âTotal renewable water resourcesâ â were recently updated with the latest available data.

May 11, 2023

The World Factbook recently updated the World âPopulationâ entry and its four superlative subfields based on data provided by the US Census Bureau. As of 2023, the Worldâs population is estimated to be 7.98 billion.Â Its most populous country is China (1.41 billion), and its least populous is the Holy See (1,000).Â The Worldâs most densely populated country is Macau (22,856.1 people per sq km) while Greenland is the Worldâs least densely populated (0.003 people per sq km).

May 4, 2023

The World Factbook has launched an exciting new product, the Africa Demographic Atlas.Â The Atlas brings together many of our population fields for African countries, including such topics as ethnic groups, languages, and religions, as well as fertility, mortality, migration, health, education, and population distribution.Â The Atlasâ maps and graphics provide geographic context and data visualization for over 50 African countries.

April 27, 2023

The World Health Organizationâs âWorld Malaria Dayâ is April 25th. Globally, the World Health Organization estimates that in 2020, 241 million cases of malaria occurred, and 627,000 people, mostly children in Africa, died of malaria.Â The World Factbook has expanded the Major infectious disease field in the World entry to focus on the global distribution of the most serious infectious diseases and has provided maps showing the disease distribution.Â In addition, the âMajor infectious diseaseâ entry for all countries has been updated with the most recent risk assessments.

April 20, 2023

In the Transnational Issues category, the âTrafficking in personsâ field has been updated with 2022 information from the State Departmentâs annual Trafficking in Persons Report.Â This year the State Department designated 34 countries as Tier 2 Watchlist (not meeting minimum standards to eliminate trafficking but making significant efforts to do so) and 22 as Tier 3 (not meeting minimum standards to eliminate trafficking and not making significant efforts to do so).

April 13, 2023

The World Factbook is pleased to announce the addition of two new Economy fields: âRemittancesâ and âAverage household expenditures.â Expressed as a percent of GDP, âRemittancesâ are the aggregate amount of personal monies that people send from one country to people in another (often family and friends) to help with expenses. âAverage household expendituresâ are the average percentages of household income spent on certain goods and commodities, and this initial release features the expenditures on food and on alcohol and tobacco.

April 6, 2023

In the Military and Security section, the âMaritime threatsâ entry â which describes piracy threats â was recently updated with 2022 numbers. Overall, the number of incidents world-wide continues to decline â 115 in 2022 compared with 132 in 2021. This total is the lowest number since 1994. Nonetheless, certain areas remain very dangerous. The majority (64%) of the attacks occurred in the waters of five countries: Bangladesh (7), Ghana (7), Indonesia (10), Peru (12), and the Singapore Straits (38).

March 30, 2023

The number of country photographs in The World Factbook now exceeds 5,000. All are in the public domain. These photographs may be viewed in a number of ways. After clicking on a countryâs Photos section, the first 12 images will show up. In the upper right, a âPer Page:â box with a dropdown arrow allows users to view more photos at a time (24, 48, or All). Once an image is selected, it appears in a larger size along with a useful scroll bar that displays icons of the five photos before and after the selected photo in the photo sequence. Check out the new photo access system and enjoy browsing the Factbookâs ever-growing photographic collection.

March 23, 2023

A large number of demographic entries in the People and Society category were recently updated with the latest 2023 data from the US Census Bureau. Among the fields updated are: âPopulation,â âPopulation growth rate,â âAge structure,â and âTotal fertility rate.â

March 16, 2023

Are you keeping up with the Fact of the Day on the Factbookâs home page? If you missed some recent entries, you can catch up in the newly added Daily Facts Archive that displays all the facts from the previous 30 days.

March 9, 2023

Appendix H: Strategic Materials has been further enhanced with the addition of photographs illustrating most of the minerals that serve as the sources for strategic materials. Detailed information on each image becomes visible when hovering over the photo.

March 2, 2023

The World Factbook is pleased to announce the addition of its 10th appendix, which displays Population Pyramids by Region. Population pyramids illustrate a countryâs age and sex structure.Â By grouping the pyramids by region, the age and sex structure of neighboring countries can be compared visually. For example, the male, working-age side of Kuwaitâs population pyramid bulges out more than the female side because of the large number of male labor migrants, while nearby Iraq has a triangularly shaped pyramid because the youth population (the base of the pyramid) is much larger than its elderly population (the upper part of the pyramid). The striking difference in age and sex structure may be seen in the new Appendix I, under âMiddle East.â

February 23, 2023

The World Factbook has completed its review and supplementation of Appendix F: Cross-Reference List of Geographic Names. This appendix now contains some 1,600 place names and their geographic coordinates. It is particularly valuable as a source of historic (former), alternate, or local names for a variety of regions, countries, cities, islands, water bodies, and other geographic features.

February 16, 2023

The World Factbook recently uploaded almost 9,000 economic data updates, including all GDP fields, âInflation rate,â âIndustrial production growth rate,â âLabor force,â âUnemployment rate,â âPublic debt,â âTaxes and other revenues,â âCurrent account balance,â âExports,â âImports,â âReserves of foreign exchange and gold,â âExternal debt,â and âExchange rates.â

February 9, 2023

âDemographic profilesâ for eight Central Asian and South Caucasus countries have recently been added to the People and Society category.Â The countries included are: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.

February 2, 2023

Updates to the âPorts and terminalsâ field include new information on liquid natural gas (LNG) terminals, container ports, and cruise ports. Germany is ramping up LNG import terminals to offset the loss of natural gas pipelines from Russia and now has three operational LNG import terminals with plans to build as many as six in total. To accelerate the availability of LNG imports, Germany is utilizing ship-based Floating Storage and Regasification Units (FSRU).

Recently released 2021 port data shows that most of the top-twenty container ports in the World in terms of âtwenty-foot equivalentâ (TEU) units continue to be in Asia, but in 2021 three US ports made the top twenty list. The most important cruise tourism destination in the World is the Caribbean Region, where tourism is vital to the economies of most of the island countries. The new update includes an expanded list of Caribbean cruise ports.

January 26, 2023

The World Factbook is pleased to introduce two new entries in the People and Society category.Â The first field is the âGross reproduction rate,â which is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she survived all of her childbearing years.Â It indicates whether the next generation of women will exceed, match, or outnumber the current population of women of reproductive age.Â The second field is âCurrently married women (ages 15-49),â which provides the percentage of married or in-union women among women of reproductive age (15-49).

January 19, 2023

Appendix H: Strategic Materials has been updated and an additional section on Alloys added. The new information supplements the existing data on Metals, Non-metals, Rare earth elements, and Compounds.

January 12, 2023

In the People and Society category, the following fields have been updated for all countries:Â âEducation expenditures,â âSchool life expectancy,â â Dependency ratios,â âContraceptive prevalence rate,â and âHIV/AIDS â adult prevalence rate.â

January 5, 2023

In Appendix B: International Organizations and Groups, three global sport governing bodies have been added: for association football (soccer), the International Association Football Federation (FIFA); for basketball, the International Basketball Federation (FIBA); and for baseball, the World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC).

December 29, 2022

Information on ocean currents in the Geography section of each of the five Oceans â Arctic, Atlantic, Indian, Pacific, and Southern â was recently transferred into its own âMajor ocean currentsâ entry, along with a map showing the Major World Ocean Currents.

In late March of this year, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) issued a Travel Alert for polio in Africa, as well as for a few Middle Eastern countries. While wild or naturally occurring polio has been virtually eradicated worldwide, a vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV) has become a concern. VDPV is a strain of the weakened poliovirus that was initially included in oral polio vaccine and that has changed over time and behaves like the wild or naturally occurring virus. This means that it can be spread more easily to people who are unvaccinated against polio and who come into contact with the stool or respiratory secretions, such as from a sneeze, of an âinfectedâ person who received oral polio vaccine. The CDC recommends that before any international travel, anyone unvaccinated, incompletely vaccinated, or with an unknown polio vaccination status should complete the routine polio vaccination series. The CDC recommendations may be found in the âMajor infectious diseasesâ entry in the People and Society section of the 24 Sub-Saharan African (and miscellaneous other) countries where VDPV is a threat.

In the World entry, the airport traffic numbers in the Transportation category have been updated with preliminary 2020 data and they present a dramatically different scenario due to COVID-19 restrictions. Passenger traffic through the top ten airports declined 45.7% in 2020 and for all airports globally dropped am amazing 64.6%. Atlanta, which had been the busiest passenger airport for more than 20 years, is now number two. Seven of the top ten airports for passenger traffic are in China and the other three are in the US. Most of the new rankings are due to domestic flights in China; when global traffic opens up again the old passenger patterns should reemerge.

In contrast, air cargo traffic in the top ten airports grew by 3% in 2020 and the rank order was largely unchanged. Memphis, TN surpassed Hong Kong to become the busiest cargo airport. All told, the top ten cargo airports handled 28% of global air cargo.

Did you know that more than three-quarters of the worldâs countries have a maritime boundary of some sort. As such, they have an exclusive economic zone (EEZ), which is a sea zone â set forth by the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea â over which a country has special rights regarding the exploration and use of marine resources. An EEZ stretches from a countryâs mean-low tide baseline at its coast out to 200 nautical miles. Most maps do not show EEZs, but The World Factbookâs World Oceans map does (under the References tab>Regional and World Maps>World Oceans; the PDF version is the most informative, particularly when enlarged). More than one-third of the worldâs ocean area falls within an EEZ.
